Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures (referred to the PDF file #15–0870 for IrO2): (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; (c) Ir/SiO2-400; (d) Ir/SiO2-500; (e) Ir/SiO2-600; and (f) Ir/SiO2-700. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images and Ir particle size distribution of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures: (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; (c) Ir/SiO2-400; (d) Ir/SiO2-500; (e) Ir/SiO2-600; and (f) Ir/SiO2-700. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HR-TEM images of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures: (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; and (c) Ir/SiO2-600. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles (A) and O2-TPD profiles (B) of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures: (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; (c) Ir/SiO2-400; (d) Ir/SiO2-500; (e) Ir/SiO2-600; and (f) Ir/SiO2-700. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Ir 4 f XPS spectra of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures: (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; (c) Ir/SiO2-400; (d) Ir/SiO2-500; (e) Ir/SiO2-600; and (f) Ir/SiO2-700. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (A) Light-off profiles of methane oxidation over the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures (1.0 vol% CH4 + 20 vol% O2 + balanced N2, WGHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1): (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; (c) Ir/SiO2-400; (d) Ir/SiO2-500; (e) Ir/SiO2-600; and (f) Ir/SiO2-700. (B) A comparison of (a) Ir/SiO2-200, (b) Pd/SiO2 and (c) Pt/SiO2 catalysts in methane oxidation (all the catalysts had the same metal loading and were evaluated under the same conditions as above specified). (C) Turnover frequency (TOF) of various Ir/SiO2-X catalysts determined at a methane conversion of below 15% with WGHSV between 20,000 and 600,000 mL g−1 h−1: (a) Ir/SiO2-200; (b) Ir/SiO2-300; (c) Ir/SiO2-400; (d) Ir/SiO2-500; (e) Ir/SiO2-600; and (f) Ir/SiO2-700. (D) Relation between the TOF values in methane oxidation measured at 340 °C and (a) the Ir particle size measured by TEM and (b) the fraction of Ir3+ species determined by Ir 4 f XPS. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (A) Ir 4 f XPS spectra of the Ir/SiO2-200 and Ir/SiO2-R catalysts. (B) Turnover frequency (TOF) of the Ir/SiO2-200 and Ir/SiO2-R catalysts for lean methane oxidation, determined at a methane conversion of below 15%. (C) In situ FT-IR spectra of Ir/SiO2-200 for lean methane oxidation at 280 °C. (D) In situ FT-IR spectra of Ir/SiO2-R for lean methane oxidation at 280 °C. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 In situ FT-IR spectra of lean methane oxidation over the Ir/SiO2-200 (A) and Ir/SiO2-700 (B) catalysts collected from 200 °C to 440 °C with an interval of 20 °C. Box 165 Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China To clarify the relationship between the structure and performance for the Ir-based catalysts, a series of Ir/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the colloid-impregnation method and evaluated in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature. The results indicate that the colloid-impregnation is effective to attain highly dispersed Ir nanoparticles on the SiO2 support. The catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2 is sensitive to the structure and state of loaded Ir species; the Ir/SiO2 catalyst with abundant defective Ir3+ species and mean Ir particle size below 2.0 nm exhibits extraordinarily high activity in methane oxidation. However, the activity of Ir/SiO2 decreases considerably with the increase of calcination temperature, due to the agglomeration of Ir particles induced by high temperature. Nevertheless, the thermal stability of supported Ir catalysts can be greatly improved by employing proper support with strengthened metal-support interaction, suggesting the enormous potential of supported Ir catalysts in the related applications. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Lean methane mitigation Catalytic oxidation Ir/SiO2 Calcination temperature Colloid-impregnation Ir species 1 Introduction Due to the great potential of methane in inducing the global warming when released into atmosphere, the anthropogenic methane emissions (most of them have a low methane concentration of 0.1–1.0 vol%) have become a serious environmental concern [1–4]. The catalytic oxidation is deemed to be an effective measure in the mitigation of lean methane [5,6]. However, it is still a great challenge to get highly active catalyst at low temperature because of the extreme stability and chemical inertness of methane molecules. Although various materials have been tested as the catalyst in methane oxidation, the noble metal Pt and in particular Pd are considered as the most active components owing to their outstanding performance in methane oxidation [4,7–19]. In spite of that, hard effort is ceaselessly devoted to the exploration of more active metal component for methane oxidation at low temperature. In this regard, although the Ir-based catalysts have shown rather attractive performance in various reactions such as hydrogenation [20–22], ring-opening [23], isomerization [24], steam reforming [25] and even the oxidation of certain hydrocarbons [26–28], they are rarely employed in methane oxidation. This is probably related to the poor stability of loaded Ir species at high temperature. As reported by Wynblatt and Gjostein [29], the thermal stability of various noble metals in the oxidizing atmosphere decreased in the order of Rh ≈ Pd > Pt > Ir > Ru, although Fiedorow and co-workers also observed that the sequence of thermal stability in the reducing circumstance was Ir > Ru > Pt ≈ Rh > Pd [30]. Nevertheless, Wang and Schmidt found that the oxidation and reduction of Ir particles was slower than that of Rh, Pt and Pd, because an oxide skin was formed over the metal core upon the partial oxidation of Ir at low temperature [31]. Moreover, Yentekakis and co-workers have conducted a series of excellent research works on the Ir-based catalyst and observed that by using the supports with high lattice oxygen ion lability, the strengthened metal-support interactions could effectively stabilize Ir and Rh nanoparticles which tended to agglomerate under oxidative thermal sintering conditions [32–36]; the stabilized Ir-based catalysts exhibited superior performance in methane reforming and nitrous oxide decomposition. In addition, Schick and co-workers investigated the size–activity relationship of Ir-based catalysts for the complete oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOC) and found that the catalytic activity decreased with the increase of Ir particle size [26]. Ohtsuka reported that Ir/ZrO2 exhibited lower activity in methane oxidation than Pd/ZrO2 and Pt/ZrO2 [37]; however, Ir could act as a promoter to enhance the catalytic performance of Pt/ZrO2. Through DFT calculation, Zhu and co-workers concluded that the C–H bond of methane dissociated facilely on the stoichiometric IrO2 (110) facets [38]. In virtue of the excellent performance of Ir-based catalysts in many reactions, in this work, the structure-performance relationship of supported Ir catalysts was investigated, in order to exploit the potential of Ir as a catalytically active component for the low temperature methane oxidation. Herein, a series of Ir/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the colloid-impregnation method and evaluated in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature, to relate the catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2 to the structure and state of loaded Ir species. Next, various metal oxides (ZrO2, TiO2, CeO2, Al2O3, La2O3 and MgO) were screened to alter the metal-support interaction and to improve the thermal stability of Ir nanoparticles. The results should help to clarify the relationship between the structure and performance for the Ir-based catalysts in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature, which should be greatly beneficial to the design of more active catalysts for methane oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Ir/SiO2 catalysts with Ir loading of 1 wt% were prepared by the colloid-impregnation method, where the Ir nanoparticles were constructed by the alcohol reduction method, as reported by Toshima [39]. Briefly, 0.23 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone K30 (PVP-K30) was added into 50 mL of the H2IrCl6∙6 H2O solution (2.1 mmol L−1), which was then mixed with 120 mL of aqueous ethanol solution (40 vol%). The mixture was then heated at 120 °C and refluxed under vigorous stirring for 3 h, to obtain a dark colloidal dispersion of Ir nanoparticles. After that, 2 g of fumed silica (SiO2, CAB-O-SIL M-5, Davisil, supplied by CABOT, with a surface area of 200 m2 g−1 and average particle size of 12 nm) were immersed in the colloidal dispersion and stirred for 4 h at room temperature; the mixture was then heated at 80 °C to evaporate the solvent. Finally, the solid substance was pretreated in 50 vol% H2/N2 at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain the Ir/SiO2-R catalyst. The Ir/SiO2-R catalyst was then subjected to calcination in static air for 2 h at different temperatures, to obtain the Ir/SiO2-X series catalysts, where X = 200, 300, 400, 500, 600 and 700, representing the calcination temperature in °C. For comparison, the Pd/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2 catalysts with a noble metal loading of 1 wt% were also prepared following the same procedures for getting the Ir/SiO2-400 catalyst, viz., they are acquired by colloid-impregnation, pretreated in 50 vol% H2/N2 at 500 °C for 2 h and then calcined in static air at 400 °C for 2 h. In addition, the Ir nanoparticles were also supported on other metal oxides including ZrO2, TiO2, CeO2, Al2O3, La2O3 and MgO (purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, with an average particle size of 50 nm) by using the same procedures, to obtain the Ir/ZrO2, Ir/TiO2, Ir/CeO2, Ir/Al2O3, Ir/La2O3 and Ir/MgO catalysts, respectively. Prior to further characterization and evaluation, these catalysts were also pretreated in 50 vol% H2/N2 at 500 °C for 2 h and calcined in static air at 400 °C for 2 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalyst samples were characterized by various techniques [12, 40, 41], including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku MiniFlex II desktop X-ray diffractometer, nitrogen physisorption at − 195.8 °C by using a TriStar II 3020 gas adsorption analyzer, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a field emission microscope (JEM-2100 F, JEOL), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 instrument, temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) on an Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer, and in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) on a Bruker Vertex 80 V FTIR spectrometer with KBr window, as also described in detail in the Supplementary Material. The temperature-programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) was conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. 50 mg of catalyst sample was loaded and pretreated at temperature for calcination (200–700 °C) for 30 min in the 2 vol% O2/Ar stream (30 mL min−1) and then cooled to 50 °C. Saturated adsorption of O2 on the catalyst was achieved by introducing gaseous O2 into the sample tube for 1 h. After that, the physically adsorbed O2 was removed by flushing the sample tube with Ar flow (30 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h. To get the O2-TPD profile, the catalyst sample was then heated up from 50° to 950°C at a ramp of 10 °C min−1, during which the amount of O2 desorbed upon heating was measured with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The CO chemisorption was also performed on the AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. 50 mg of the catalyst sample was first pretreated at 250 °C for 1 h in the 10 vol% H2/Ar stream (30 mL min−1) and then cooled to 50 °C; multi-pulses of CO was then introduced until saturated adsorption. The dispersion of Ir species was then derived from the quantity of CO adsorption by assuming that a surface Ir site could stoichiometrically coordinate two CO molecules. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic activity in lean methane combustion was evaluated at atmospheric pressure in a quartz fixed-bed reactor with an internal diameter of 6 mm [40,41]. For each test, 100 mg of the catalyst sample (40–60 mesh) was placed in the quartz tube, filled with quartz sand and separated by quartz cotton. The feed gas of 1 vol% CH4 + 20 vol% O2 + 79 vol% N2 was introduced into the reactor at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1, corresponding to a weight-based gas hourly space velocity (WGHSV) of 30,000 mL h−1 g−1. The reactor was then heated from 200 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C min−1, until a complete conversion of CH4 was achieved. The effluent products were analyzed online at a temperature interval of 20 °C by using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014C) equipped with a post-column methanator and a flame ionization detector (FID). The temperatures corresponding to a methane conversion of 10%, 50% and 90% are denoted as T 10%, T 50% and T 90%, respectively. In addition, the turnover frequency (TOF, h−1) of various Ir/SiO2-X catalysts was also determined at a methane conversion of below 15% by altering the space velocity, on the basis of Ir dispersion measured by CO chemisorption using following formula: TOF = x CH 4 × F × C 0 × 60 × M Ir 22414 × w cat × L Ir × D Ir where F is the standard feed flow rate (mL min−1), C 0 is the feed methane concentration (vol%), M Ir is the atomic mass of Ir (192.22 g mol−1), w cat is the mass of catalyst loaded in the reactor (g), D Ir is the Ir dispersion and L Ir is the loading of Ir metal on the catalyst (wt%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of Ir/SiO2 As given in Table 1, all the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts present a similar surface area in the range of 156–182 m2 g−1, slightly lower than that of the fumed silica support (200 m2 g−1), suggesting that the impregnation, reduction and calcination treatments only have a minor effect on the textural properties of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts (compared to the SiO2 support) due to the relatively low content of Ir and high thermal stability of SiO2 support. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts upon calcination at different temperatures. Apparently, all the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts display dominantly the diffraction patterns of amorphous SiO2 support. For Ir/SiO2-200 calcined at 200 °C, no diffraction peaks attributed to iridium oxide or metallic iridium are detected, suggesting that the iridium species are highly dispersed on the SiO2 support. In contrast, very weak peaks at 27.9°, 34.7° and 54.2° appear in the diffraction pattern of Ir/SiO2-300 calcined at 300 °C, which are assigned to the (110), (101) and (211) crystal facets of IrO2, respectively [42]. Moreover, the intensity of the IrO2 diffraction peaks for the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts increases considerably with the increase of calcination temperature, indicating the severe agglomeration of IrO2 particles upon calcination at high temperature. The IrO2 crystallite size can be estimated using the Scherrer formula; as given in Table 1, the Ir particle size for Ir/SiO2-200 and Ir/SiO2-300 is below 5 nm, whereas Ir/SiO2-400, Ir/SiO2-500, Ir/SiO2-600 and Ir/SiO2-700 display the mean Ir particle sizes of 5.5, 9.0, 12.9 and 18.0 nm, respectively. The TEM images and corresponding Ir particle size distribution of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 2. Apparently, Ir/SiO2-200, Ir/SiO2-300 and Ir/SiO2-700 display round particles of iridium oxide, whereas the Ir species on Ir/SiO2-400, Ir/SiO2-500 and Ir/SiO2-600 take mainly a rod-like morphology. In addition, for Ir/SiO2-200 and Ir/SiO2-300, the iridium oxide nanoparticles are highly dispersed on the SiO2 support, with the mean particle size of 2.0 and 2.6 nm, respectively. With the increase of calcination temperature from 400° to 700°C, the Ir nanoparticles agglomerate considerably and the mean Ir particle size increases from 5.5 to 17.6 nm. In addition, the Ir dispersion and the average diameter of Ir particles can also be estimated from CO chemisorption, as given in Table 1; in fact, there is a good agreement among the average Ir particle sizes determined by different methods including XRD, TEM and CO adsorption. Fig. 3 presents the HR-TEM images of the Ir/SiO2-200, Ir/SiO2-300 and Ir/SiO2-600 catalysts, to observe the exposed crystalline nature of Ir species. The crystal fringes (d (hkl)) of 2.25 Å is attributed to the lattice spacing of metallic Ir (111) plane, whereas the inter-planar distances of 1.69, 2.58 and 3.21 Å are assigned to the lattice spacing of (211), (101) and (110) planes of IrO2, respectively [43]. Highly dispersed iridium nanoparticles exposing Ir (111) plane are distinctly observed on Ir/SiO2-200. However, upon the calcination at a temperature above 300 °C, the iridium nanoparticles begin to aggregate and coalesce into larger IrO2 particles. Similar high agglomeration propensity was also reported for the Ir nanoparticles supported on Al2O3 under oxidative thermal sintering conditions [32,33], which could be however obviated by using other supports like gadolinia-doped ceria (GDC) and alumina-ceria-zirconia (ACZ) with high surface O2− mobility. Fig. 4A depicts the H2-TPR profiles of various Ir/SiO2-X catalysts. For Ir/SiO2-200 calcined at 200 °C, there is a hydrogen consumption peak around 74 °C, which should be attributed to the surface IrO x species formed on the highly dispersed iridium nanoparticles; this peak for Ir/SiO2-X shifts to higher temperature and fades away gradually with the increase of calcination temperature. Meanwhile, a new reduction peak appears at about 170 °C for Ir/SiO2-300 calcined at 300 °C; it shifts slightly to higher temperature and the intensity increases considerably for the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts with the increase of calcination temperature. The relative hydrogen consumption of per mol Ir during the H2-TPR measurement is also provided in Table 1. Obviously, Ir/SiO2-200 consumes much less hydrogen (H2/Ir = 0.57) than other Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at higher temperatures. Meanwhile, the hydrogen consumption of Ir/SiO2-X increases first with the calcination temperature, reaches the maximum value of H2/Ir = 1.22 for Ir/SiO2-400 and then decreases slightly to H2/Ir = 1.10 for Ir/SiO2-700. All these suggest that for Ir/SiO2-200, Ir is present as iridium nanoparticles covered with surface IrO x . With the increase of calcination temperature, the Ir nanoparticles on Ir/SiO2-X begin to aggregate and coalesce into larger particles, accompanying with the incorporation of surface IrO x into the sublayers to form bulk IrO2. In addition, the maximum hydrogen consumption (H2/Ir = 1.22) for all Ir/SiO2-X catalysts is less than the stoichiometric value (H2/Ir = 2) for a complete reduction of IrO2. It is probably ascribed to the sintering of nano iridium particles upon the severe calcination, which may kinetically hinder the penetration of oxygen into the inner sintered iridium core [31,44]. Fig. 4B displays the O2-TPD profiles of various Ir/SiO2-X catalysts. The oxygen desorption peak below 100 °C is attributed to the physically adsorbed oxygen, whilst the electrophilic oxygen species (O− and O2 −) on the catalyst surface are desorbed at 100–400 °C and the release of lattice oxygen occurs at above 600 °C [45,46]. Apparently, Ir/SiO2-200 shows a distinct peak around 100–400 °C attributed to the surface oxygen species, which could promote the activation of methane molecules as well as the oxidation of reaction intermediates [46]. In contrast, the desorption peaks attributed to the surface oxygen species for Ir/SiO2-300, Ir/SiO2-500 and Ir/SiO2-700 are rather inconspicuous and the peaks ascribed to the lattice oxygen also shift to higher temperature, suggesting that the Ir–O bonds are strengthened with the increase of calcination temperature, in agreement with the H2-TPR results. Wang and co-workers investigated the change of Ir/SiO2 in the morphology of Ir species in the oxidizing atmosphere and observed that iridium oxide emerged at about 300 °C and large amount of iridium oxide was formed around the metal particles at 700 °C, whereas a complete oxidation of the Ir particles needed a temperature up to 900 °C [31]. This is similar to the three-step oxidation of metal palladium particles demonstrated by many researches [44, 47–49], viz., the adsorption of oxygen on the surface of Pd particles, the penetration of surface oxygen into the sublayer, and finally the formation of bulk PdO. As for the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts upon calcination, above results indicate that a layer of IrO x is formed on metallic Ir nanoparticles at 200 °C; the thickness of the IrO x layer increases gradually with the increase of calcination temperature and the sintering of IrO2 becomes much evident at a temperature above 400 °C. The oxidation states of surface Ir species were further characterized by Ir 4 f XPS, as shown in Fig. 5. Three peaks are deconvoluted at around 60.8, 61.6 and 62.3 eV, which are assigned to Ir0, Ir3+ and Ir4+ species, respectively [23, 50, 51]. Apparently, the valence states of iridium species on the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts are related to the calcination temperature. Only Ir/SiO2-200 displays a typical peak attributed to metallic iridium, whilst other Ir/SiO2-X catalysts show iridium species of Ir3+ and Ir4+ in different proportions. As given in Table 1, with the increase of calcination temperature from 200° to 700°C, the proportion of Ir3+ species for Ir/SiO2-X decreases from 61% to 40%, whereas the fraction of Ir4+ species increases from 15% to 60%, consistent with the above TEM, H2-TPR and O2-TPD results. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts in lean methane oxidation Fig. 6 A displays the light-off profiles of lean methane oxidation over the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures. Apparently, the calcination temperature has a significant influence on the catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2; that is, the catalytic activity decreases considerably with the increase of calcination temperature. The Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst calcined at 200 °C exhibits the highest catalytic activity in lean methane oxidation and the temperatures corresponding to a methane conversion of 10% and 90% (T 10% and T 90%) are 256 and 348 °C, respectively. In contrast, the activity of Ir/SiO2-600 calcined 600 °C declines drastically and T 10% and T 90% are raised to 361 and 505 °C, respectively. The Ir/SiO2-700 catalyst calcined at 700 °C performs even worse in lean methane oxidation and T 10% reaches 436 °C. Fig. 6B shows a comparison of Ir/SiO2-200 with the Pd/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the similar methods in lean methane oxidation. Apparently, the overall activity of Ir/SiO2-200 is comparable to that of Pd/SiO2, but much superior to that of Pt/SiO2. The T 10% values of Ir/SiO2, Pd/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2 are 256, 281 and 467 °C, respectively, suggesting that Ir/SiO2-200 has the highest activity among three catalysts in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature. In addition, as demonstrated in Fig. S1 of the Supplemental material, the apparent activation energy of the Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst in methane oxidation is about 102 kJ mol−1, comparable to that of Pd/ZSM-5 [40]. Moreover, a rough comparison of current Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst with some other supported noble metal catalysts in their activity for the lean methane oxidation was also given in Table S1 of the Supplementary material. Apparently, current Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst prepared by the colloid-impregnation method exhibits rather high activity in the lean methane oxidation, in comparison with most of those catalysts reported in the open literature. It should be mentioned that some Ir/SiO2 catalyst samples calcined at a very low temperature are tested at a relatively higher temperature. In this case, naturally, as the low calcination temperature cannot adequately stabilize the active Ir sites, the state and structure of the iridium species and thereon the catalytic activity may undergo certain changes during the lean methane oxidation reaction at a higher temperature (e.g. during the light-off tests). This should be indeed avoided in practice; however, these unusual tests were here just used to examine the temporary and/or extreme activity of unstabilized active Ir species. Furthermore, besides the light–off tests, the turnover frequency (TOF) of various Ir/SiO2-X catalysts was also determined at different temperatures with a methane conversion of below 15%, where the state and structure of the iridium species should not undergo a considerable change in a short time, in order to have an objective comparison among various catalysts in their initial intrinsic activity for the lean methane oxidation at low temperature. As shown Fig. 6 C, the intrinsic catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2-X for lean methane oxidation at low temperature decreases markedly with the calcination temperature. As given in Table 1, for the Ir/SiO2-X catalysts, the Ir particle size increases whereas the fraction of surface Ir3+ species decreases with the increase of calcination temperature. When the TOF value is correlated with the Ir particle size or the fraction of surface Ir3+ species, as shown in Fig. 6D, it is clearly observed that the catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2-X is rather sensitive to the surface Ir3+ fraction and in particular the Ir particle size. That is, a highly active Ir/SiO2 catalyst in lean methane oxidation may request rather small Ir particles (< 3 nm) and Ir3+ is probably the most active species for the Ir/SiO2 catalyst in methane oxidation. A comparison between the uncalcined Ir/SiO2-R catalyst and the Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst in the state of surface Ir species and their catalytic performance in lean methane oxidation was illustrated in Fig. 7. Apparently, the pristine Ir/SiO2-R catalyst is totally dominated by the metallic Ir0 species, whereas Ir/SiO2-200 contains both the Ir0 (24%) and IrO x species (61% Ir3+ and 15% Ir4+), as demonstrated in Fig. 7 A and Table 1. When two catalysts were evaluated in the lean methane oxidation, as illustrated in Fig. 7B, Ir/SiO2-200 always displays a relatively higher activity than Ir/SiO2-R, suggesting that the IrO x species is catalytically more active in methane oxidation than the metallic Ir0 species. In addition, as a large fraction of metallic Ir0 (about 76%) has turned into the IrO x species upon calcination in static air at 200 °C, it is unlikely that the metallic Ir0 species can survive intact as the main active Ir species in the oxidative atmosphere with excess oxygen for lean methane oxidation at a temperature much higher than 200 °C. In fact, as verified in Fig. 7 C and 7D, a distinct band appears at 2075–2100 cm−1 in the in situ FT-IR spectra of both Ir/SiO2-200 and Ir/SiO2-R for lean methane oxidation at 280 °C. This band shifts slightly towards higher wave number with the proceeding of reaction, viz., from 2075 to 2098 cm−1, corresponding to a transition of the Irδ+–CO species to the Ir3+–CO species [52–54], regardless of either over Ir/SiO2-200 or over Ir/SiO2-R. Hence, it is rather reasonable to suppose that Ir3+ is the major active species for the Ir/SiO2 catalyst in lean methane oxidation. Similarly, for the Pd/SiO2 catalyst in lean methane oxidation, our previous work also proved that the catalytic activity of Pd/SiO2 is related to the oxidation state of Pd species (besides the size and dispersion of Pd particles); the catalytic activity of various Pd species followed the order of PdO x >> Pd > PdO [41]. To get insight into the reaction mechanism of methane oxidation over Ir/SiO2, the Ir/SiO2-200 and Ir/SiO2-700 catalysts were comparatively characterized by the in situ FT-IR spectroscopy [40]. As shown in Fig. 8, over the Ir-SiO2-200 catalyst, the signals of CO2 at around 2340 and 2360 cm−1 appear at 260 °C and their intensity increases with the reaction temperature. Over the Ir-SiO2-700 catalyst, in contrast, the signals of CO2 only emerge at a temperature above 400 °C and their intensity is also rather lower compared to that over Ir-SiO2-200, consistent with the rather lower activity of Ir-SiO2-700 in methane oxidation (Fig. 6). The intensity of the band for CH4 at 3015 cm−1 decreases gradually with the increase of reaction temperature, in particular over Ir-SiO2-200, corresponding to the higher methane conversion at higher temperature. In addition, in the FT-IR spectra for methane oxidation over the Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst (Fig. 8A), the bands attributed to the formats at 1382 and 1590 cm−1 emerge at 240 °C and their intensity increases with the increase of temperatures. The bands for the carbonates at 1460 and 1560 cm−1 appear at 280 °C and their intensity also increases with the increase of temperatures [55,56]. Current results suggest that the formats and carbonates species are the surface intermediate species for lean methane oxidation. In contrast, although the Ir/SiO2-700 catalyst displays the similar FT-IR spectra (Fig. 8B), the bands for the intermediates and products from methane oxidation over the Ir/SiO2-700 catalyst always emerge at much higher temperatures than those over the Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst, corresponding to the lower activity of Ir/SiO2-700 in methane oxidation. The in situ FT-IR results agree well with the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism proposed by Zasada and co-workers for the methane oxidation at low temperature [57]. That is, as demonstrated in Fig. 9, gaseous oxygen is first adsorbed and activated to form O* and the active O* species can then promote the dissociation of CH4 into –CH3 and –OH; after that, –CH3 and –OH are dehydrogenated to generate H+ and CH2O and CH2O is then rapidly oxidized to HCOO–; finally, HCOO– is then oxidized to the carbonate species by the active O* , to generate CO2. In addition, as reported previously, the dissociation of CH4 to –CH3 acted as the rate-determining step for methane oxidation [40,58]. In the in situ FT-IR spectra, the bands for the intermediates and products from methane oxidation over Ir/SiO2-200 always emerge at much lower temperatures than those over Ir/SiO2-700, demonstrating that the ability of Ir/SiO2-200 in the activation of both methane and oxygen is much greater than that of Ir/SiO2-700, corresponding well to the superior catalytic activity of the former Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst. 3.3 About the stability of supported Ir catalysts in lean methane oxidation Above results illustrate that Ir supported on SiO2 (Ir/SiO2-200) has very high catalytic activity in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature. Meanwhile, it is also observed that the activity of Ir/SiO2 is rather sensitive to the calcination temperature; a high temperature for calcination leads to a serious agglomeration of Ir particles and the abatement of active Ir3+ species, resulting in a severe deterioration in the catalytic performance of Ir/SiO2. Such an event suggests a poor thermal stability of Ir/SiO2 for methane oxidation at relatively high temperature. In fact, as shown in Fig. 10 A, for the lean methane oxidation over Ir/SiO2-200, the conversion of methane keeps almost stable with the time on stream (in 24 h) at a temperature below 300 °C, whereas the conversion of methane drops considerably from 90% to 40% within 24 h at 340 °C. It means that the catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2-200 is relatively stable for methane oxidation at a temperature below 300 °C, in accord with the above observation that the average Ir particle size maintains below 3 nm and the Ir3+ species dominates on the catalyst surface when Ir/SiO2 is calcined at a temperature below 300 °C (Table 1). This is probably ascribed to the weak interaction between the Ir nanoparticles and SiO2 support. As reported by Murata and co-workers, for the supported Pd catalyst, the size and oxidation state of Pd particles and the catalytic activity were related to metal-support interaction, which could be regulated by altering the support materials [59]. As a preliminary effort to improve the thermal stability of supported Ir catalysts, besides SiO2, several other metallic oxides such as ZrO2, TiO2, CeO2, Al2O3, La2O3 and MgO were used as the support to regulate the metal-support interaction. As shown by the XRD patterns and TEM images in the Figs. S2 and S3 of the Supplementary material, for all the Ir catalysts of different supports, the Ir species are highly dispersed, with the mean particle size in the range of 1.2–1.7 nm. When these Ir catalysts of different supports are employed in the lean methane oxidation, as presented in Fig. 10B, their activity in methane oxidation at low temperature decreases in the order of Ir/SiO2-200 > Ir/ZrO2 > Ir/TiO2 > Ir/CeO2 > Ir/Al2O3 > Ir/La2O3 > Ir/MgO. That is, just next to Ir/SiO2-200, the Ir/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits adequate activity in the lean methane oxidation and the temperatures for a methane conversion of 10% and 90% (T 10% and T 90%) are 301 and 383 °C, respectively. The catalytic stability of Ir/ZrO2 was then evaluated in various manners. As shown in Fig. 11 A, for three cycles of heating up and cooling down light-off tests, all the conversion profiles overlap heavily, indicating that the catalytic activity of Ir/ZrO2 in methane oxidation changes little during these series of light-off tests. Fig. 11B further shows the conversion of methane over the Ir/ZrO2 catalyst with the time on stream at a constant temperature of 320 and 380 °C. During the 200 h tests, the conversion of methane at 320 °C increases slightly from 19% to 31%, whilst it decreases slightly from 92% to 82% at 380 °C, suggesting the excellent thermal stability of the Ir/ZrO2 catalyst in lean methane oxidation at relatively high temperature. In summary, Ir supported on inert SiO2 (Ir/SiO2-200) with a mean Ir particle size of about 2 nm (dominated by surface Ir3+ species) exhibits very high catalytic activity in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature, but suffered from serious deterioration in activity at high temperature due to its poor thermal stability. However, as demonstrated with the Ir/ZrO2 catalyst, the stability of supported Ir catalyst can be greatly improved by employing proper support with strengthened metal-support interaction. This closely coincides with the observation of Yentekakis and co-workers that by using the supports like CeO2-ZrO2, Al2O3-CeO2-ZrO2 and Gd2O3-CeO2 with high lattice oxygen ion lability, the strengthened metal-support interactions could effectively stabilize the Ir nanoparticles which tended to agglomerate under oxidative thermal sintering conditions [32–36]. Accordingly, it is also highly expected that the supported Ir catalyst may deliver outstanding performance in methane oxidation when appropriate measures are adopted to entrench the active surface Ir species and to inhibit the agglomeration of Ir nanoparticles, such as physically shielding or encapsulating the Ir nanoparticles as well as chemically regulating the metal-support interactions. 4 Conclusions A series of Ir/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the colloid-impregnation method and evaluated in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature, in order to clarify the relation of catalytic activity to the structure and state of Ir species as well as to exploit the potential of Ir as a catalytically active component for the low temperature methane oxidation. The results indicate that the colloid-impregnation method is effective to attain highly dispersed Ir nanoparticles on the SiO2 support. The catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2 is rather sensitive to the structure and state of Ir species. The Ir/SiO2-200 catalyst (calcined at 200 °C) displays a mean Ir particle size of 2.0 nm with abundant defective Ir3+ species and exhibits excellent activity in the low temperature methane oxidation; the temperatures corresponding to a methane conversion of 10% and 90% are 256 and 348 °C, respectively, much superior to those ever reported before. However, the catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2 decreases considerably with the increase of calcination temperature, as a high temperature is conducive to the agglomeration of Ir particles and the decrease of highly reducible and defective Ir3+ species. Although the Ir/SiO2 catalyst shows relatively poor tolerance to high temperature, the thermal stability of supported Ir catalyst can be greatly improved by employing proper support with strengthened metal-support interaction. In particular, the Ir/ZrO2 catalyst displays both relatively high activity and greatly improved thermal stability in the lean methane oxidation. Owing to the extraordinary high activity of Ir nanoparticles in the catalytic oxidation of methane, the supported Ir catalysts may have enormous potential in the related applications, in particular when appropriate measures are adopted to entrench the active surface Ir species and to inhibit the agglomeration of Ir nanoparticles, like physically shielding or encapsulating the Ir nanoparticles as well as chemically regulating the metal-support interactions. coredata.dc:description: To clarify the relationship between the structure and performance for the Ir-based catalysts, a series of Ir/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the colloid-impregnation method and evaluated in the lean methane oxidation at low temperature. The results indicate that the colloid-impregnation is effective to attain highly dispersed Ir nanoparticles on the SiO2 support. The catalytic activity of Ir/SiO2 is sensitive to the structure and state of loaded Ir species; the Ir/SiO2 catalyst with abundant defective Ir3+ species and mean Ir particle size below 2.0 nm exhibits extraordinarily high activity in methane oxidation. However, the activity of Ir/SiO2 decreases considerably with the increase of calcination temperature, due to the agglomeration of Ir particles induced by high temperature. Nevertheless, the thermal stability of supported Ir catalysts can be greatly improved by employing proper support with strengthened metal-support interaction, suggesting the enormous potential of supported Ir catalysts in the related applications.
coredata.dc:title: Structure and performance of supported iridium catalyst for the lean methane oxidation at low temperature
